Executive Summary
The last Resubmission was December 17, 2007.

Prevention and Response Policies
It is the policy of the City of College Station, Texas, to operate safe water treatment facilities, reducing to the greatest extent possible any hazards associated with our processes, and reducing any subsequent risk to the surrounding community, our employees, and the environment.  It is also our policy to work with the surrounding community and local emergency response agencies, and promote a spirit of cooperation and teamwork, to orchestrate an effective contingency plan in the unlikely event that a process incident occurs at on of our plants.

Primary Activity
The primary activity at the Sandy Point Road Pump Station is municipal water disinfection and distribution.

Use of Regulated Substance
Chlorine is used primarily as a disinfectant prior to distribution in the drinking water supply.

Quantity Handled or Stored
Chlorine: 14,000 pounds

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The Sandy Point Road Pump Station area is in compliance with the RMP Rule, 40 CFR 68.  The staff has conducted a comprehensive review of all Facility systems, as well as administrative, technical, operation, and maintenance procedures, in addition to the other required program elements of the rule.

Five Year Accident History
The Sandy Point Road Pump Station has never had a significant release of a hazardous substance as defined by this Rule.

Emergency Response Program
This facility has an Emergency Response Program that is coordinated with the community plan.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Events that will continue to improve safety at the facility are:
*  Water Production employees are issued updated operating procedures and are trained using the procedures.
*  Emergency Response Procedures are reviewed revised as appropriate.
